results.title: Brother sun sister moon
results.creator_credit: Franco Zeffirelli, Luciano Perugia and Euro International
results.brief_description: This delicate, handsome, quasi-fictional biography of one of the great saints of the Catholic Church, Francis of Assisi, focuses on the early years of his life. Saint Francis, who sought communion with the natural world by renouncing his family;s riches to seek his own destiny unencumbered by material possessions. Francis was, in a sense, history’s first “drop-out” ; he left a life of comfort to seek a spiritual union with the world. Starring Graham Faulkner as Francis and Judi Bowker as the young girl who eventually sheds her materialistic existence for religious poverty, this visually stunning film was nominate for a Best Art Direction Academy Award in 1973.

results.title: Brother bear
results.creator_credit: Bob Walker, Aaron Blaise and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: Disney animated feature film about North American Indian boy Kenai (voice by Joaquin Phoenix) who is mysteriously transformed into a bear. Kenai then has to view the world through the eyes of the bear, providing him (and the viewer) with important lessons in life. He is befriend by a bear cub, Koda, who accompanies him through his journey, encountering a range of other wildlife and humans along the way. Features songs by Phil Collins.

results.title: Brother
results.creator_credit: Takeshi Kitano, Masayuki Mori, Jeremy Thomas, Bac Films (France), Film Four International, Recorded Picture Company and Office Kitano
results.brief_description: Takeshi “Beat” Kitano went to the United States of America to film this cross-cultural gangster Yakuza film. Takeshi himself plays an exiled yakuza hitman who lands in Los Angeles with a bag of stolen money and resentful of his banishment from the home country. He finds his half-brother (Omar Epps) and together they attempt to take over the drug trade in Los Angeles. A return to highly kinetic crime fiction, “Brother” finds Takeshi Kitano in a much more playful mood after the personal reflections of “Hani-Bi”. Whipping furiously across the genre tropes of the gangster film and the Yakuza film, “Brother” emerges as a highly satisfying ride with deftly executed sequences of violence and warrior mayhem. The cultural differences between the two brothers - one being Japanese and the other being African-American - allows for some genuinely funny reflections on cultural and ethnic misunderstandings, but nothing allows the action to stop for a moment. In Japanese and English with English subtitles.

results.title: Brother
results.creator_credit: Adam Elliot and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Through the narration, we recall events in the lives of two young brothers growing up in the suburbs. We learn about “getting the blame” for things you didn’t do, and that if the devil doesn’t get you then karma will. Above all we see how two brothers deal with an alcoholic father, disease and asthma. Narrated by William McInnes. This clay animation film forms part of the autobiographical trilogy that includes “Uncle”, “Brother” and “Cousin”.

results.title: Brother
results.brief_description: The childhood memory of a brother, his cigarette butts, asthma and head lice. An exploration of the simple truths and ironies that make up a life. An iconic Australian film.

results.title: Broome and the Pearl Coast
results.creator_credit: Martyn Down, John Mabey, Rhonda Mabey, AFFC and Sorena
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
Broome, in the remote north-west of Australia is famous for its pearling industry. Travelling the breadth of the Pearl Coast, Ted Egan encounters a number of extraordinary people like Yoshinori Maeda who came to Australia as a young man to fish, but decided to stay. The vast panoramic coast and desert of the north-west is explored, including the beautiful splendour of Deepwater Point, 200kms from Broome.

results.title: Bronzed Aussie gods
results.creator_credit: Michael Murray, Nick Bleszinski and Light Source Films
results.brief_description: The Beach is part of Australia’s cultural landscape, the surf lifesavers the guardians of this beautiful, but potentially dangerous terrain. Saving lives is not all these lifesavers do, at the end of every summer the Australian National Surf Lifesaving Titles (affectionately referred to as the “Aussies” by lifesaving aficionados) are held in April on the Gold Coast. Featuring over 6,000 competitors, this prestigious event is the second largest sporting event in number of athletes only to the Olympics. ‘Bronzed Aussie Gods’ follows three groups of men and women in training as lifesavers, performing real life rescues, enjoying their work, and vying for title glory. Interspersed with their plight is a trip down memory lane courtesy of archival footage capturing the changing customs and costumes that celebrate Australia’s unique relationship with the beach. This results in a film which celebrates Australian beach culture and maps the evolution of a strong aspect of Australian identity.

results.title: Bronze boy
results.creator_credit: David Sims, David H. Fowler, Geoffrey Scott and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 228 of Series “Parade”.
A step-by-step record of the creation in 1969 of a life-sized statue of “Young Nick”, a cabin boy on Captain Cook’s ship “Endeavour”. The sculptor, Auckland’s Frank Szirmay, speaks about his work.

results.title: Bronze
results.creator_credit: Pierre Moretti, Francois Seguillon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film presents the conception and execution of a work of art - a monumental bronze work by Montreal sculptor Charles Daudelin, now standing outside the National Arts Centre in Ottawa. Shows the shaping of the model in its styrofoam stage with knife, saw and blowtorch. The film is without words, but with music to evoke the mood. Credits: Photography by Thomas Vamos and Michel Thomas-d’Hoste; edited by Yves Leduc; music by Maurice Blackburn and sound by Claude Delorme.
